last_name: Mitee, PhD (Law) LLM BL LLB HND (Town Planning)
sub_title: Legal Information Technologist, Legal Academic, Legal Innovator, Former Legal Research Consultant to the United Nations, Human Right of Free Access to Law Pioneer Global Advocate, Indigenous Rights Advocate, Author
summary:
Dr. Leesi Ebenezer Mitee holds a multidisciplinary PhD in international human rights law, legal information technology (legal informatics), indigenous customary law and indigenous rights. He is a chief lecturer of law (equivalent of associate professor of law) and a former legal research national consultant to the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) on the 1998 PCASED project that provided the juridical foundations for the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) 1998 Moratorium which culminated in a regional multilateral treaty: ECOWAS Convention on Small Arms and Light Weapons, their Ammunition and other Related Matters 2006. He devised the <.officiallaws) official public legal information generic top-level domain (gTLD) system for easy identification of the reliable versions of the laws published online worldwide; developed the system of nationally networked one-stop official public legal information websites (NOPLIW system) for optimal findability and management of online law databases; invented the human rights-based public access-adequate huricompatisation model of ascertainment of indigenous customary law; formulated the new human rights-advocacy approach (NHRAA) that consists of ten criteria for the recognition of new human rights; and pioneered the global advocacy of the recognition of the right of free access to public legal information as a substantive human right in 2017 (https://publiclegalinformation.com). 
His New Human Right of Free Access to Public Legal Information Book Series consists of 22 modern academic article-style independent but interconnected chapters of four books: 
•	Developments in Human Rights Law and the New Human Right of Free Access to Public Legal Information: The New Human Rights-Advocacy Approach and the Ten Criteria for the Formal Recognition of New Human Rights (Volume 1) — ISBN 9789083108520 (eBook) 9789083108506 (paperback); 
•	The New Human Rights-Based Huricompatisation Model of Ascertainment of Indigenous Customary Law: Strategies for Adequate Local and Global Public Access (Volume 2) — ISBN 9789083108568 (eBook) 9789083108544 (paperback); 
•	Innovative Technological Mechanisms for Adequate Web-Based Access to National and Global Public Legal Information (Volume 3) — ISBN 9789083108513 (eBook) 9789083108582 (paperback); and 
•	A Model Empirical Study of the Current State of Governmental Provision of Free Access to Nigerian Public Legal Information (Volume 4) — ISBN 9789083108551 (eBook) 9789083108537 (paperback). 
Email: info@koinonialegal.com Website: https://publiclegalinformation.com

Law (Public Access to Legislation and Human Rights)

education.degree_name: Barrister-at-Law (BL) Postgraduate Professional Legal Practice Certificate

projects.title: Invention of the Huricompatisation Model and Process of Ascertainment of Indigenous Customary Law Using the Human Rights-Based Approach (HRBA)
projects.description:
Huricompatisation, the model and process I invented, is a public access-adequate and human rights-compliant mechanism for systematically recording or transmitting all the binding oral or unwritten rules of each community’s indigenous customary law into writing. 

I coined the new legal word "huricompatisation" in 2017 as the term for my invention, details of which are available on my Human Right of Free Access to Public Legal Information Advocacy (HURAPLA) website: https://publiclegalinformation.com/

company.name: The Institute of Legal and Global Studies

profile_positions.company: The Institute of Legal and Global Studies
profile_positions.title: Chief Lecturer of Law (Equivalent of Associate Professor)

profile_positions.description: I was engaged by the United Nations as the National Consultant (Nigeria) for the Project RAF/97/025: Capacity Development for Social Reconciliation. The goal of the Project was to research and analyse legislation on Arms (Weapons) Control in Mali, Cameroon, Nigeria, and Ghana with a view to assessing the juridical foundations of the West Africa Moratorium on Small Arms (light weapons). The Project provided the juridical foundations for the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) Declaration of a Moratorium on the Importation, Exportation and Manufacture of Light Weapons in West Africa (31 October 1998). The Moratorium culminated in the ECOWAS Convention [Treaty] on Small Arms and Light Weapons, their Ammunition and other Related Matters 2006.
profile_positions.title: Law Research Consultant
